page.title: 04Staploe, Bushmead Priory
page.content: The Bushmead Estate is a wooded and farmed area of great beauty, owned by the Wade-Gery family since 1552. Their Georgian mansion was demolished in 1965 but there are still many attractive buildings, the jewel being the Refectory of an Augustian Priory, founded about 1195. After many alterations, following its dissolution, first as a house, then as stabling, while the rest was progressively dismantled, the Refectory in 1973, was placed in the care of English Heritage who have recently repaired and opened it to the public. The buildings chief glory is the magnificent timber roof, a rare and beautiful example of crown-post construction, dated around 1250. There are also, mediaeval wall-paintings and stained glass. The original fishponds are situated, nearby, in the valley.
